title: Greyfriars Bobby,
author: Atkinson, Eleanor (Stackhouse)
snippet: Heroes of Sebastopol answered the summons of drum and bugle in the Castle and fired the hearts of Edinburgh youth. Cannon all around them, and "theirs not to reason why," this little band stormed out Queensferry Street and went down, hand under hand, into the fairy underworld of Leith Water,

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: After crossing from Queensferry Street over Princes Street, into Lothian Road, some instinct he could never afterwards fathom, caused him to prefer the left side of the street to the right. This was contrary to what we may term the principles of "automatic psychology."

title: By Adverse Winds. [A novel.]
author: Smeaton, William Henry Oliphant.
snippet: As he passed by, his tall, well-knit figure attracted the notice of two of the night constables standing at the corner of Queensferry Street and Princes Street. They recognised him and touched their helmets, remarking, as they gazed after him—

title: Greyfriars Bobby,
author: Atkinson, Eleanor (Stackhouse)
snippet: Straight down the length of the empty market the laddies ran, through the crooked, fascinating haunt of horses and jockeys in the street of King's Stables, then northward along the fronts of quaint little handicrafts shops that skirted Castle Crag. By turning westward into Queensferry Street a very few minutes would have brought them to a bit of buried country. But every expedition of Edinburgh lads of spirit of that day was properly begun with challenges to scale Castle Rock from the valley park of Princes Street Gardens on the north.
